name: 2-fluorobenzoic acid
Reason: The basic unit for 2-fluorobenzoic acid is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The influence of the carboxylic acid group significantly increases the melting point due to its ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, both within the molecule and with other molecules, as well as due to the rigidity it imparts to the molecular structure. We can estimate this effect to be +170 degrees Celsius. The fluorine atom, being electronegative, also introduces strong dipole-dipole interactions and slightly increases the rigidity of the molecule, which can raise the melting point. We can estimate this effect to be +10 degrees Celsius. Therefore, adding these contributions to the base value of benzene, we get a preliminary prediction for the melting point of 2-fluorobenzoic acid.

name: 2-fluorobenzoic acid
Reason: The basic unit for 2-fluorobenzoic acid is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The carboxylic acid group is known to significantly increase the melting point due to its ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds and increase molecular rigidity; this can be estimated as a +100 degrees Celsius increase. The influence of the fluorine atom introduces additional dipole-dipole interactions and a small degree of rigidity to the molecule. These factors combined typically raise the melting point by around +20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, summing these effects to the base value of benzene gives a predicted melting point for 2-fluorobenzoic acid.
